remixlab.proscene

Class CameraProfile

  • java.lang.Object
    • remixlab.proscene.CameraProfile

  • public class CameraProfile
extends java.lang.Object
    This class encapsulates a set of camera keyboard shortcuts, and camera and frame mouse bindings which together represent a "camera mode".

    Proscene handle the following kind of actions:

    1. Keyboard actions which can be general such as draw the world axis (see Scene.setShortcut(Character, remixlab.proscene.Scene.KeyboardAction)) or can be associated to a camera profile to affect the camera behavior, such as move the camera to the left. Different versions of setShortcut() are provided to set camera keyboard shortcuts.
    2. Click actions such as selecting an object. This class provide different versions of setClickBinding() to bind click actions.
    3. Mouse actions (i.e., the mouse is clicked and then dragged) which can be handle by the camera or an interactive frame (such as rotating the camera or an interactive frame). This class provide different versions of setCameraMouseBinding(), setFrameMouseBinding() setCameraWheelBinding() and setFrameWheelBinding() to bind the mouse actions.

    Note: Click and mouse actions can also be handled by MouseGrabbable objects, but their implementation is entirely customizable and thus it depends on your application. The InteractiveFrame class is actually a MouseGrabbable object and hence it provides one such implementation.

    Once instantiated, to use a camera profile you need to register() it (unregister() performs the inverse operation).

    This class also provide some useful preset bindings which represents some common "camera modes": ARCBALL, WHEELED_ARCBALL, FIRST_PERSON, THIRD_PERSON, and CUSTOM (see mode()). A custom camera profiles represents an empty set of camera and keyboard shortcuts. Most of the methods of this class provide means to define (or overwrite) custom (or preset bindings). Default keyboard shortcuts and mouse bindings for each CameraProfile preset are defined as follows:

    ARCBALL

    1. Keyboard shortcuts
      • Up -> Move camera up
      • Down -> Move camera down
      • Left -> Move camera to the left
      • Right -> Move camera to the right
      • S -> Show the whole scene
      • s -> Interpolate the camera to fit the whole scene
      • + -> Increase camera rotation sensitivity
      • - -> Decrease camera rotation sensitivity
    2. Camera mouse bindings
      • Button1 -> Rotate frame
      • Shift+Button1 -> Zoom on region (camera or interactive drivable frame)
      • Button2 -> Zoom
      • Button3 -> Translate frame (camera or interactive frame)
      • Shift+Button3 -> Screen rotate (camera or interactive frame)
    3. Mouse click bindings
      • Button1 + 2 clicks -> Align camera with world
      • Button2 + 2 clicks -> Show the whole scene
      • Button3 + 2 clicks -> Zoom to fit the scene
    4. Interactive frame mouse bindings
      • Button1 -> Rotate frame (camera or interactive frame)
      • Button2 -> Zoom
      • Button3 -> Translate frame (camera or interactive frame)

    WHEELED_ARCBALL

    1. Keyboard shortcuts
      • Right -> Move camera to the right
      • Left -> Move camera to the left
      • Up -> Move camera up
      • Down -> Move camera down
      • S -> Show the whole scene
      • s -> Interpolate the camera to fit the whole scene
      • + -> Increase camera rotation sensitivity
      • - -> Decrease camera rotation sensitivity
    2. Camera mouse bindings
      • Button1 -> Rotate frame (camera or interactive frame)
      • Shift+Button1 -> Zoom on region (camera or interactive drivable frame)
        • *
      • Button2 -> Zoom
      • Button3 -> Translate frame (camera or interactive frame)
      • Shift+Button3 -> Screen rotate (camera or interactive frame)
    3. Mouse click bindings
      • Button1 + 2 clicks -> Align camera with world
      • Button2 + 2 clicks -> Show the whole scene
      • Button3 + 2 clicks -> Zoom to fit the scene
    4. Interactive frame mouse bindings
      • Button1 -> Rotate frame (camera or interactive frame)
      • Button2 -> Zoom
      • Button3 -> Translate frame (camera or interactive frame)
    5. Camera mouse wheel bindings
      • Wheel -> Zoom
    6. Interactive frame mouse wheel bindings
      • Wheel -> Zoom

    FIRST_PERSON

    1. Keyboard shortcuts
      • S -> Show the whole scene
      • s -> Interpolate the camera to fit the whole scene
      • + -> Increase camera fly speed
      • - -> Decrease camera fly speed
    2. Camera mouse bindings
      • Button1 -> Move forward frame (camera or interactive frame)
      • Shift+Button1 -> Roll frame (camera or interactive drivable frame)
      • Button2 -> Look around with frame (camera or interactive drivable frame)
      • Button3 -> move backward frame (camera or interactive frame)
      • Shift+Button3 -> Drive (camera or interactive drivable frame)
    3. Interactive frame mouse bindings
      • Button1 -> Rotate frame (camera or interactive frame)
      • Button2 -> Zoom
      • Button3 -> Translate frame (camera or interactive frame)

    THIRD_PERSON

    1. Keyboard shortcuts
      • A -> Decrease camera azymuth respect to the avatar
      • a -> Increase camera azymuth respect to the avatar
      • I -> Decrease camera inclination respect to the avatar
      • i -> Increase camera inclination respect to the avatar
      • t -> Increase camera tracking distance respect to the avatar
      • T -> Decrease camera tracking distance respect to the avatar
      • + -> Increase avatar fly speed
      • - -> Decrease avatar fly speed
    2. Interactive frame mouse bindings
      • Button1 -> Move forward frame (camera or interactive frame)
      • Shift+Button1 -> Roll frame (camera or interactive drivable frame)
      • Button2 -> Look around with frame (camera or interactive drivable frame)
      • Button3 -> move backward frame (camera or interactive frame)
      • Shift+Button3 -> Drive (camera or interactive drivable frame)

    The Scene provides proper methods to manage (and also register and unregister) camera profiles, such as Scene.cameraProfile(String), Scene.currentCameraProfile(), Scene.setCurrentCameraProfile(CameraProfile), among others.

    Attention: Every instantiated scene provides two camera profiles by default: WHEELED_ARCBALL and FIRST_PERSON. If you define an Scene.avatar() (for instance with Scene.setAvatar(Trackable)) then you should register at least one THIRD_PERSON camera profile to your Scene.

    • Constructor Detail

      • CameraProfile

        public CameraProfile(Scene scn,
             java.lang.String n)
        Convenience constructor that simply calls this(scn, n, Mode.CUSTOM).

      • CameraProfile

        public CameraProfile(Scene scn,
             java.lang.String n,
             CameraProfile.Mode m)
        Main constructor.

        This constructor takes the scene instance, the custom name of the camera profile and an enum type defining its mode which can be: ARCBALL, WHEELED_ARCBALL, FIRST_PERSON, THIRD_PERSON, CUSTOM.

        If you define a Scene.avatar() (for instance with Scene.setAvatar(Trackable)) then you should register at least one THIRD_PERSON camera profile to your Scene.

        Except for CUSTOM, each camera mode loads some preset camera and keyboard shortcut bindings. A custom camera profiles represents an empty set of camera and keyboard shortcuts.

        Parameters:
        scn - the scene object
        n - the camera profile name
        m - the camera profile mode

    • Method Detail

      • mode

        public CameraProfile.Mode mode()
        Returns the camera profile mode.

        The camera profile mode is defined at instantiation time and cannot be modified later.

        See Also:
        CameraProfile(Scene, String, Mode)

        public boolean isRegistered()
        Returns true if the camera profile is registered at the scene and false otherwise.
        See Also:
        register(), unregister()

      • register

        public boolean register()
        Registers the camera profile at the scene. Returns true if registration succeeded (if there's a registered camera profile with the same name, registration will fail).

        Convenience wrapper function that simple calls scene.registerCameraProfile(this).

      • unregister

        public void unregister()
        Unregisters the camera profile from the scene.

        Convenience wrapper function that simple calls scene.unregisterCameraProfile(this).

        Binds the click-action to the given binding.
        Parameters:
        button - binding
        action - action to be binded

      • setClickBinding

        public void setClickBinding(java.lang.Integer mask,
                   Scene.Button button,
                   Scene.ClickAction action)
        Binds the click-action to the given binding.
        Parameters:
        mask - modifier mask defining the binding
        button - mouse button defining the binding
        action - action to be binded Attention: Mac users should avoid using the CTRL modifier key, since its use is reserved to emulate the right button of the mouse.

      • setClickBinding

                   java.lang.Integer nc,
                   Scene.ClickAction action)
        Binds the click-action to the given binding.
        Parameters:
        button - mouse button defining the binding
        nc - number of clicks that defines the binding
        action - action to be binded

        button - mouse button defining the binding
        nc - number of clicks that defines the binding
        action - action to be binded Attention: Mac users should avoid using the CTRL modifier key, since its use is reserved to emulate the right button of the mouse.
